image.altText: A man stands beside the rootball of a tree with a diameter twice the height of him

props.synopsis: Tasmanians are working to repair damage from floods and high winds that hit the state over the past week, but the window of calm weather may be small with a new front expected to develop later in the week.

title.children: Reprieve in wild weather for Tasmania, as state works to repair damage from flooding and high winds

image.altText: A road can be see through the windscreen of a military vehicle

props.synopsis: For the first time in more than five years and since the Ukraine war began, the ABC crosses into Russia to see what life is like in the occupied city of Sudzha.

title.children: After Ukraine's incursion into Russia, we get a glimpse of life behind Vladimir Putin's iron curtain

image.altText: A swimming pool surrounded by plants in a city area, with tall buildings in the background.

props.synopsis: One of Australia's leading hospitality groups, Merivale, has been accused of fostering a culture that places women at risk, condones drug use by staff and patrons and fails to adequately address claims of sexual assault.

title.children: Former Merivale worker says she was forced to serve 'really rapey' customers

image.altText: A large group of people hold TWU banner saying 'Carrying Australia'

props.synopsis: The TWU says an internal investigation has forced the union to disband the Victorian-Tasmania branch, after it revealed significant issues and "unfounded" harassment allegations against its leadership.

title.children: Transport Workers' Union dissolves branch, claiming 'significant operational and cultural issues'

image.altText: A row of coal loaders.

props.synopsis: A 22-year-old woman charged over her involvement in blocking coal trains in the Hunter Valley is "relieved" after successfully appealing against her jail sentence.

title.children: Tasmanian protester wins appeal against three-month jail sentence for blocking Newcastle coal trains

image.altText: A person in a hi-vis putting a chain around a tyre.

props.synopsis: Police say they are "gobsmacked" and the premier calls it "stupidity" after a group of more than a dozen bushwalkers, including children, were rescued in treacherous weather conditions on kunanyi/Mt Wellington.

title.children: Police 'gobsmacked' after walkers, including kids, rescued on freezing kunanyi/Mt Wellington summit

image.altText: Yahya Sinwar, with grey hair and beard, has a serious expression.

props.synopsis: The US Department of Justice announces criminal charges against Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar and other senior militants in the first formal action taken by American law enforcement over the October 7 terrorist attack.

title.children: US Justice Department announces criminal charges against Hamas militants

image.altText: Mad on left holds cupcakes while sitting next to another man and woman

props.synopsis: The post on the embassy's official Instagram account celebrated "Wear it Purple Day" and expressed dedication to creating "a supporting environment where everyone, especially LGBTQIA+ youth, can feel proud to be themselves".

title.children: Iran summons Australia's ambassador in Tehran over pro-LGBT Instagram post

image.altText: A baby with red hair.

props.synopsis: On one hand, mothers and midwives are sounding the alarm about critical understaffing in Royal Hobart Hospital's maternity ward. But on the other, the department says its records show everything is fine.

title.children: Mothers and midwives paint a picture of a crisis. So why does the department say all is fine at Royal Hobart Hospital?

image.altText: The words ‘No Change To WA GST’ have been scrawled on a reporter's arm and signed by Anthony Albanese.

props.synopsis: The GST deal has been described as "the worst public policy decision in Australia so far this century" but none of the major parties will touch it for fear of upsetting Western Australia.

title.children: The major parties are stuck in a $53b GST trap — because no-one dares anger the Vengeful Deity of the West

image.altText: A koala facing towards the right of frame sits on a road, the koala fills the whole image and the background is only asphalt.

props.synopsis: We examined approved and proposed projects under federal environment legislation to look at how much koala habitat is being slated for destruction across several industries.

title.children: Thousands of hectares of koala habitat are cleared every year, including for renewable energy projects

image.altText: Side by side photos of the Treasurer Jim Chalmers looking serious and Michele Bullock, gesturing with her hand mid-speech

props.synopsis: New figures published today are expected to again show the Australian economy growing weakly overall but shrinking in per person terms, highlighting the strain on households which economists say has been masked by migration.

title.children: Economists say migration is propping up growth and masking household pain, but cutting it won't make or break recession fears

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek

props.synopsis: Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek said a recent stock price rise in the company behind the gold mine that she blocked on Indigenous heritage grounds shows some shareholders still see a pathway.

title.children: 'Nonsense': Plibersek downplays likelihood of major delays after her rejection of NSW gold mine proposal

image.altText: A picture of a large new casino building

props.synopsis: Queensland's Office of Liquor and Gaming Revenue is facing renewed scrutiny over its decision to grant a licence for The Star Brisbane casino last week, in light of another report deeming the company unsuitable as a Sydney casino operator.

title.children: Queensland regulator's move to grant a new Brisbane casino licence under fire

image.altText: The Star, formally known as Star City Casino, Sydney.

props.synopsis: Cash isn't the only thing in short supply at Star Entertainment. Time is also running out for newly installed chief executive Steve McCann to get a deal across the line.

title.children: Time is running out for Star Entertainment to secure a rescue package

image.altText: Adam Bandt press club

props.synopsis: When the Greens proposed an extra super-profits tax on the excessive part of really excessive profits last week, business and the government acted as if the sky was about to fall in. But the principle behind the idea is a good one — as Labor and the Business Council should know better than anyone.

title.children: The Greens want a super-profits tax. Labor and business used to like the idea too

image.altText: Alex Saffy in action during the 100m butterfly S10

props.synopsis: The 18-year-old broke down into tears during an emotional post-swim interview in one of the most memorable moments at the Paris Paralympics. Follow the action in our live blog.

title.children: 'Just a lot of emotions': Aussie teenager Alex Saffy breaks down into tears after winning butterfly bronze

image.altText: a person pins a red awareness ribbon to their white shirt

props.synopsis: New numbers show HIV diagnoses have reduced by a third over the past decade despite a 2023 increase.

title.children: Australia ready for 'the end of AIDS' as HIV diagnoses continue to decrease

image.altText: A police car parked near a beach, with the ocean visible in the distance.

props.synopsis: At least 12 people are dead after a boat carrying migrants capsized in the English Channel on its way to Britain, the French Interior Minister said on Tuesday, adding that two other people are missing.

title.children: At least 12 dead after migrant boat capsizes in English Channel

image.altText: A man in a paddock with a phone to his ear

props.synopsis: Regional residents are concerned the existing 4G network may put people in danger and won't be reliable once 3G is shutdown.

title.children: As the 3G shutdown looms, anxiety is growing over regional phone coverage

image.altText: Drone photo of house with border marking the boundary

props.synopsis: Thousands of Aussies are ditching real estate agents to maximise profits when they sell, but there are things you should know before you sell privately.

title.children: Nic saved $11k by selling his home privately. He is one of thousands of Aussies doing the same

image.altText: A nurse extracts a vaccine from a small vial into a syringe.

props.synopsis: Two new COVID-19 vaccines targeting the JN.1 variant are under review by the TGA. We asked experts about the new vaccines and what we can expect if they're approved.

title.children: New COVID vaccines could soon be available. So when's the best time to get a booster?

image.altText: A beluga whale being fed fish from a boat.

props.synopsis: The death of a friendly beluga "spy whale" with a mysterious past shows the complex relationship between humans and wildlife, with conservationists split on how best to protect the animal until the end.

title.children: There were plans to relocate Hvaldimir the Russian 'spy whale'. He died before they came to fruition

image.altText: Alex de Minaur

props.synopsis: Dubbed an honorary Brit during Wimbledon, Alex de Minaur says he's starting to feel the hostility from British fans as he prepares to face Jack Draper in the US Open.

title.children: 'I feel a little bit of hostility': De Minaur puts aside British links as he prepares for blockbuster US Open quarterfinal

image.altText: Palm trees throughout a valley of stepped rice paddies

props.synopsis: Bali boasts world-famous beach clubs, surf breaks and ancient Hindu temples. The only problem is, you often have to battle traffic to get to them.

title.children: Eat, pray, traffic jam: Bali's heaving roads may become a thing of the past with a $29 billion train line

image.altText: Tim Tszyu has his hand raised with a belt across his shoulder

props.synopsis: Tim Tszyu earns a chance to claim the super-welterweight belt after locking in an October fight with unbeaten Russian Bakhram Murtazaliev.

title.children: Tszyu gets a chance to emulate his famous dad as fight with undefeated Russian locked in

image.altText: An Indigenous woman with short hair looks at the camera, sitting in her office.

props.synopsis: Labor bled votes to both the left and the right to lose the recent Northern Territory election in a hammering. Its new leader says the party will now review its policies.

title.children: Labor was demolished by the CLP in an NT election landslide. How will it find its way back?

image.altText: The exterior of the NAAJA building in Darwin.

props.synopsis: Former executives of one of Australia's largest Aboriginal legal services are calling on the board to resign after a string of controversies.

title.children: 'Sick to my stomach': Former executives reveal why they quit NT's largest Aboriginal legal service

image.altText: A close-up image of hands holding a mobile phone

props.synopsis: Researchers also found no association between radio waves from mobile phone towers, or workplace radio wave exposure, and any type of cancer.

title.children: 'No association' between mobile phone use and brain cancers, WHO research says

image.altText: Building with sign 'Liverpool City Council'

props.synopsis: A Liverpool City Council building in south-west Sydney has been ruled out as the site of a cancer cluster after a thorough testing process.

title.children: A Sydney council building has been cleared as a cancer cluster source. But why does this phenomenon happen?

image.altText: A dark haired woman and young girl sit on a couch with their arms around each other smiling.

props.synopsis: Canberran Femke Matthews was shocked to learn it would take a three-hour drive to access the medical care needed to treat her daughter Ashley, who was diagnosed with leukemia at seven.

title.children: Canberra doctors referring patients interstate 'every single day'

image.altText: Men walk down the road next to grey wall

props.synopsis: The terrorist group said the bombing was in response to Muslim prisoners being transferred to the "notorious 'Bagram' prison".

title.children: Islamic State group claims responsibility for deadly Kabul suicide bombing

image.altText: Two men walk past a military guard

props.synopsis: Living in Russia's shadow, Mongolia is not in a position to put President Vladimir Putin offside. But when he came to visit, the nation's obligations to the International Criminal Court were put into stark relief.

title.children: 'Truly astonishing': Why Mongolia rolled out the red carpet for Putin instead of arresting him

image.altText: Woman in red dress stands in front of abandoned construction site

props.synopsis: Darwin builder Kassiou Constructions has abandoned several partly-built homes, leaving families hundreds of thousands of dollars out of pocket.

title.children: Construction company abandons Darwin home builds, leaving families in 'nightmare' scenarios'

image.altText: Woman with fair hair and man with grey hair stand together in formal clothes.

props.synopsis: Senator Linda Reynolds's lawyer tries to eviscerate Brittany Higgins's defamation defence by painting her as a deliberate liar who tried to ruin her former boss's career and bring down the Morrison government.

title.children: Linda Reynolds's lawyer attacks 'arrogant' Brittany Higgins for trivialising senator's hurt from the 'sanctity of France'
